G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant acted as Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and other applicable Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential tenancy in Massachusetts includes a covenant that the tenant shall have the quiet enjoyment of the premises free from any acts or omissions of the landlord or persons acting under the landlord’s control which substantially interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 19.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 1, 19 and related provisions, the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, has jurisdiction over this action because the Premises are located within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court and the claims arose there.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: The tenancy is, and at all relevant times has been, a residential tenancy governed by G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was responsible for maintaining the structure and exterior of the Premises, including the basement walls and any water intrusion issues, in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (see G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was responsible for maintaining the structure and exterior of the Premises, including the basement walls and any water intrusion issues, in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (see G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.).

105 C.M.R. 410.500.proposition: The presence of water intrusion and excessive moisture in a basement apartment is a condition that can adversely affect the health and safety of the occupant and can constitute a violation of the State Sanitary Code, including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.500 and related provisions requiring that dwellings be maintained free of chronic dampness and water penetration.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly ties the landlord’s statutory and common-law duty to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions (including compliance with the State Sanitary Code) to liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for interference with quiet enjoyment. It holds Gem liable under § 14 because it failed to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions after notice, permitting repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that a landlord’s failure to correct serious State Sanitary Code violations, after notice, can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in the context of a landlord’s failure to take measures to remove drug‑dealing nontenants and provide reasonable security, not in the context of State Sanitary Code violations or physical conditions. The court expressly cabins State Sanitary Code issues to the warranty of habitability analysis and declines to expand the warranty to cover nonphysical defects; its quiet‑enjoyment discussion centers on failure to act against criminal activity, not failure to correct sanitary‑code conditions. Thus, this case does not stand for the proposition that non‑correction of serious State Sanitary Code violations, after notice, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment… We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns noise from a bar operated by another tenant and holds that, because the landlord created and could control that situation, the resulting noise constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. It does not involve or discuss violations of the State Sanitary Code, nor a landlord’s failure to correct such code violations after notice. Thus, while it supports the broader principle that a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions within their control can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically address State Sanitary Code violations as framed in the proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat, which is required by the State Sanitary Code, “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.” The court treats the lack of heat (a serious sanitary code violation) after notice as actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and rejects financial inability as a defense, thereby confirming that such failure can be a breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment but does not state that failure to correct serious State Sanitary Code violations after notice can constitute a breach. Instead, it recites the general standard that quiet enjoyment protects against serious interference, generally requiring landlord notice and at least negligence, and then holds there was no breach because the landlord promptly made repairs. The case neither holds nor suggests that unremedied serious Sanitary Code violations after notice amount to a breach; it simply finds no interference on these facts.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. ... Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. ... The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that water intrusion, chronic dampness, and related unsanitary conditions can constitute violations of the State Sanitary Code and give rise to damages and rent abatements.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that failure to provide adequate heat and hot water constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and a violation of the State Sanitary Code, and that such breaches support rent abatement. However, the case does not discuss water intrusion, chronic dampness, or related unsanitary conditions; its facts and analysis are limited to loss of heat and hot water. Thus it cannot be cited specifically for the proposition that Massachusetts courts have recognized water intrusion and chronic dampness as Sanitary Code violations leading to damages and abatements.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover either his actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees, even if he is self-represented.
*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).support_reasoning: The opinion in Meikle v. Nurse concerns whether a tenant may use violations of the security deposit statute as a defense to possession in a summary process action under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, does not discuss the measure of damages or treble rent under § 14, and does not address entitlement to attorney’s fees—much less whether they are available to a self‑represented litigant. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).relevant_excerpt: Indeed, the security deposit statute provides for treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 15B (7). Thus, it would be contrary to legislative intent to interpret “violation of any other law” in a manner that would undermine a tenant’s right to assert the range of protections available under the summary process statute.

*Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co.*, 349 F. S.raw_text: *Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co.*, 349 F. Supp. 2d 71 (D. Mass. 2004)
*Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co.*, 349 F. S.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover either his actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees, even if he is self-represented.
*Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co.*, 349 F. S.case_name: Armstrong v. Rohm and Haas Co., Inc.
*Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co.*, 349 F. S.support_reasoning: The opinion in Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co. is an employment/contract dispute about an alleged oral promise of outsourced work. It does not involve G.L. c. 186, § 14 (a landlord-tenant statute), does not discuss statutory damages, and does not address recovery of attorney’s fees by a self-represented litigant. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition about remedies under c. 186, § 14.
*Armstrong v. Rohm & Haas Co.*, 349 F. S.relevant_excerpt: Finally, plaintiffs have failed to state a claim for violation of Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A because the instant dispute arose during the parties’ employment relationship.

*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 1.proposition: Plaintiff’s late payment of October 2025 rent, which was subsequently paid in full with the late fee, does not excuse Defendant’s ongoing statutory obligations to maintain the Premises and to avoid interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case concerns tenants who withheld rent for multiple months and raises issues of implied warranty of habitability, code compliance, interdependence of rent and repair covenants, and statutory defenses to nonpayment. It does not address whether a tenant’s single late rent payment—later cured in full with late fees—affects the landlord’s ongoing statutory duties to maintain the premises or to respect quiet enjoyment. The opinion assumes those statutory and code-based obligations exist and discusses how they interact with nonpayment of rent, but it does not hold that a tenant’s late (but fully paid) rent would relieve a landlord of such duties. Thus it does not affirmatively support the specific proposition stated.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “The second step required for the removal of the roadblock is the reversal of the present common law rule that the obligation of the tenant to pay rent and the obligation, if any, of the landlord to repair or maintain the rented premises are independent, and the substitution therefor of a new rule that such obligations are substantially mutually interdependent. The opinion of the court accomplishes this.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions or inactions substantially interfere with the tenant’s ability to use the premises as a dwelling, regardless of the landlord’s subjective intent.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord—i.e., some degree of fault and notice or reason to know—not merely substantial interference irrespective of intent. While the court acknowledges that intentional or malicious conduct is not required, it expressly rejects strict or no-fault liability and insists on negligence/foreseeability as a prerequisite, which conflicts with the proposition that liability attaches regardless of the landlord’s subjective intent or fault. Thus, the case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”
